page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY,DOWNS,EDINGTON
page.content: There are four barrows on the slopes of Edington Down and one each on Tenantry Down and Coulston Down. The long barrow on Tinhead Hill was excavated in the eighteenth century and beeches planted on it. The boundary between Bratton and Edington was marked by four stones.The original ones were described in a charter of 968 AD,they were replaced in l575, two remain today. The boundary still goes in a straight line south to Scalland Cross on the Imber Road at the edge of the block. The stone in Luccombe Bottom supposedly marks the spot where King Alfred ordered Danish prisoners to be killed in 878AD. In l955, when watercress beds were dug, skeletons were found lying face down with their hands tied behind them. Historians think the site of the Battle of Ethandune is hereabouts.
